message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination are highly suspicious for non-accidental trauma, so the most appropriate next step is to notify Child Protective Services. The other options are not appropriate until the situation has been fully investigated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggests possible child abuse, which must be reported immediately to Child Protective Services. Hospitalization and further evaluation may be necessary, but reporting is the first step. Screening for defective type I collagen is not necessary in this case. Surgical treatment may be necessary in the future, but it is not the next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a nondisplaced spiral fracture and a rib fracture in a 3-year-old with a history of recent trauma and delayed presentation suggests possible child abuse. Therefore, the most appropriate next step would be to notify Child Protective Services. The other options are not indicated at this point and may cause unnecessary harm or delay in appropriate management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination findings raise concern for non-accidental trauma, and thus the most appropriate next step in management is to notify Child Protective Services. Surgical treatment would not be appropriate without addressing the suspected abuse. Screening for defective type I collagen would not be helpful in this scenario. Hospitalization for further evaluation may be necessary, but notifying Child Protective Services is the first step in ensuring the safety of the child.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical exam findings are concerning for non-accidental trauma, also known as child abuse. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to notify Child Protective Services for further investigation and protection of the child. The other options are not indicated at this point in time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests possible child abuse/neglect. The physician has a duty to report any suspicion of child abuse or neglect to the appropriate authorities, so option A is the correct answer. Options B, C, and D are not appropriate at this time as the focus should be on ensuring the child's safety and well-being.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a spiral fracture of the arm and a fracture with callus formation of the rib suggests child abuse. The appropriate next step is to notify Child Protective Services for further evaluation and management. Options B, C, and D are not appropriate in this situation as they do not address the potential issue of child abuse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of fractures and tenderness along the left 8th rib suggest that the injury is not due to a simple fall but rather may be a result of child abuse. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to notify Child Protective Services. The other options are not appropriate until further evaluation and confirmation of the cause of the injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of trauma and an x-ray indicates fractures. The tenderness along the rib suggests that the injury may not be accidental. Therefore, it is important to notify Child Protective Services to investigate possible abuse. The other options are not appropriate at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The scenario is suggestive of child abuse, as there is no history of trauma and the injury seems to have been noticed after a long period of time. The physician should notify child protective services for further evaluation and management. Option B is not appropriate as surgical treatment may not be needed for a nondisplaced spiral fracture. Option C is not relevant in this scenario as there is no suspicion of a genetic disorder. Option D may not be necessary if there are no signs of severe injury or complications that require hospitalization.
